content:
" 'Unable to log in at server. Probably wrong configuration, username or password'. I have tried all the passwords it can be but nothing works."

If you do not use the correct username and password after you configure the account to the server's specifications, Thunderbird cannot access your account. Your statement, "I have tried all the passwords it can be but nothing works." tells me that you are not sure what the password is, and that's probably the problem.

Please check with your email ISP (server-host) for instructions about correctly accessing your account with the correct username, password, and settings.
creator: danawilson001

content:
I fail to see any problem. You have an already available section of Local Folders in Thunderbird. Anything in Local-Folders folders is completely out of reach when your server comes calling to sync. There are no limits in TB to the sizes of your Local-Folders folders or the number of them you want to set up.

Take everything you want to keep out of the hands of your mail server by establishing your storage folders under Local Folders, copy everything you want to keep to the folders you've established, and then wipe your server's folders as you wish. Your server will wipe your synced folders accordingly.

Once you've copied the keepers to your local folders, you can clean up your server through synced Thunderbird by selecting the deletes in TB synced folders (not local folders) and wiping away to your heart's content.

Don't forget to empty the Trash.
creator: danawilson001

content:
Who is your email server online? Gmail, Mailfence, ...?

The only folders in the Local Folders when Thunderbird is installed are Trash and Outbox (Drafts). Any other folders in Local Folders were added by the user. The Sent folder should be above the Local Folders level, under a mail account.

Are you using IMAP or POP? When you use a browser to go to your email server's site, do you see a Sent folder in your folder list there?
creator: danawilson001

content: Antivirus quello di sistema di MS, la casella in globale è di 4GB, suddivisa in una diecina di sottocartelle
creator: bragosso

content:
Dipende da cosa intendi per "abbastanza grossa". E dipende anche da come hai suddiviso la posta. Se la posta è suddivisa in cartelle e sottocartelle in modo che su disco si resti di dimensioni ragionevoli (diciamo max 2 GB) le prestazioni sono migliori.

Se invece una cartella è molto grande, Thunderbird diventa più lento perché prima di mostrare i messaggi deve caricare il file corrispondente.

L'altra causa tipica di questi rallentamenti è l'azione dell'antivirus che a sua volta è tanto più impattante quanto grande è il file da esaminare.
creator: @next

content: Per esempio disattivando il controllo dell'antivirus sugli allegati...

content: POP does not give you access to server-side folders. This has always been the case. IMAP, on the other hand, gives you access to server-side folders.
